text: so 24 years ago I was brought to the New
Yorker as art Editor
to rejuvenate what had by then become a
somewhat State
institution and to bring in new artists
and to try to bring the magazine from
its Ivory Tower into engaging with its
times and it was just a right thing for
me to do because I've always been
captivated by how an image can a simple
drawing can cut through the torrent of
images that we see every single day how
it can capture a moment how it can
crystalize a social Trend or complex
event in a way that a lot of words
wouldn't be able to do and reduce it to
its Essence and turn it into a cartoon
so I went to the library and I looked at
the first cover drawn by re Irvin in
1925 a Dandy looking at a butterfly
Swiss
monacle and we call it eustus Tilly and
I realized that as the magazine had
become known for its well in depth
research and long reports some of the
humor had gotten lost along the way
because now often us toly was seen as a
hotty Dandy but in fact in
1925 when rein first Drew this image he
did it as part of a Humor Magazine to
amuse the useth of the era which was the
flappers of the Roaring
20s and in the library I found the image
is that really captured the zist of
let's say a great depression and it
showed us not just how people dressed or
what the cars looked like but also what
made them laugh what their Prejudice SAR
and you really got a sense of what it
felt like to be alive in the 30s so I
called on contemporary
artists such as Adrian Tamina here I
often call on narrative artists
cartoonists children's book authors and
I give them themes such as you know what
it's like to be in the Subway or
Valentine's Day and they send me
sketches and once the sketches are
approved by the editor David
remnick um it can it's a go and I love
the way those images are
actually um not telling you what to
think but they do make you think cuz
the re the artist is actually like it's
almost a puzzle the artist is drawing
the dots and you the reader have to
complete the picture so to get this
image on the left by Anita Kun or the
one on the right by toor anuka you have
to play Spot the
differences and it is something that
it's really exciting to see how the
um the the engagement with the reader
how those images really capture that
play with the stereotypes but when you
get it it rearranges the stereotypes
that are in your head but the images
don't just have to show people sometime
it can be a feeling uh right after
September
11th I was at a point was like everybody
else where I really didn't know how to
deal with what we were going through and
I felt that no image could capture this
moment and I wanted to just do a black
cover like no cover and I talked to my
husband cartoonist art
spigelman and mentioned to him that I
was going to propose that and he said oh
if you're going to do a black cover then
why don't you do the silhouette of of
the Twin Towers black on black and I sat
down to draw this and as soon as I saw
it a shiver run down my spine and I
realized that in this refusal to make an
image we had found a way to
capture loss and mourning and
absence and it's it's been a profound
thing that I learned in the process at
sometime some of the
images that say the most do it with the
most spare
means and and a simple image can speak
volume so this is the image that we
published by Bob stack right after the
election of Barack
Obama um in captured a historic moment
but we can't really plan for this
because in order to do this we have to
let the artist experience the emotions
that we all feel uh when that is
happening so back in November 2016
during this the election last year the
only image that we could publish was
this which was understand on the weeks
that everybody voted um CU we knew
somebody would feel
this when the result of the election was
announced and and when when we found out
out the result um we really were at a
loss and this is the image that was sent
by Bob stack again and that really hit a
cord and again we can't really
like figure out you know what's going to
come next but here it felt like we
didn't know how to move forward but we
did move forward and this is the image
that we publish after Donald Trump's
election and at the time of the women's
March all over the
US so over those 24 years I have seen
like over a thousand images come to life
week after week and I'm often ask which
one is my favorite but I can't pick one
because what I'm most proud of is how
different every image is one from the
other and that's due to the talent and
the diversity of all of the artists that
contribute and now well now we're owned
by Russia
so in rendering by Barry Blitz here uh
eustus has become eustus
vladimirovich uh Tilly and the Butterfly
is none other than a flabbergast to
Donald Trump flapping his wing trying to
figure out you know how to control the
butterfly effect and the f logos that
was drawn by re Irving in
1925 is now in
cilic so what makes me really excited
about this moment is the way
that you know a free press is essential
to our
democracy and we can see from the
sublime to the ridiculous that artist
can capture what is going on in a way
that an artist armed with just India ink
and watercolor
can capture and enter into the cultural
dialogue and it puts those artists at
the center of that culture and that's
exactly where I think they should be
because the main thing we need right now
is a good cartoon thank
[Applause]
you
